Graphical abstract The Co catalyst using hydrotalcite-derived Mg(Al)O as support shows promising catalytic activity for low-temperature CH4-CO2 reforming. Under a wide range of reaction conditions, that is T = 773–1023 K, CH4/CO2/N2 = 25/25/50–50/25/25, WHSV = 60,000–120,000 mL h−1 g−1, and TOS = 25–200 h, the Co catalyst exhibits stable activity and high coke resistance. The performance is superior to the Ni counterpart which readily deactivates at 773 K due to severe coke deposition. The initial coking rate on the Co catalyst was estimated to be about 1/20 times that on the Ni catalyst. The kinetic study suggests that the dissociative adsorption of CH4 is favored on the Ni catalyst, whereas the Co catalyst has high affinity for CO2 adsorption. The results of CH4-TPSR and direct CH4 decomposition experiments further reveal that the Co catalyst is much less active for carbon formation through CH4 decomposition. It is deduced that a combination of lower activity for CH4 dissociation/decomposition and higher affinity for CO2 adsorption as well as a stronger metal-support interaction is responsible for the higher coke resistance of the Co catalyst. Keywords Methane carbon dioxide reforming Synthesis gas Cobalt catalyst Layered double hydroxides 1 Introduction The dry reforming of methane to synthesis gas using carbon dioxide has received worldwide attention [1–3]. Carbon dioxide is regarded as a major contributor to global warming, and methane has a global warming potential 25 times that of CO2. On the other hand, synthesis gas is the feedstock for Fischer-Tropsch and methanol synthesis. Nonetheless, CH4-CO2 reforming is highly endothermic, and high temperatures (>973 K) are required to achieve acceptable CH4 and CO2 conversions. To reduce energy input, CH4-CO2 reforming at lower temperatures (e.g. 673–773 K) has become a research focus [4–8]. The conversions of CH4 and CO2 can be above thermodynamic equilibrium values by using membrane reactors for selective removal of H2. There is also an emerging interest in driving the endothermic reaction using solar energy. The use of a chemical energy transmission system (CETS) using parabolic troughs as solar collector (operated below 873 K) for methane thermal reforming appears to be a promising technology [9,10]. A literature survey would reveal that most of the Group VIII metals are catalytically active for CH4-CO2 reforming [11–13]. Furthermore, despite the better performance of precious metals such as Rh and Ru, their use in large-scale applications is limited due to high cost and poor availability. To reduce the cost for commercial production, the use of non-precious metals such as Ni and Co as catalyst is preferred. Industrially, Ni catalysts are applied for CH4-H2O reforming, and it is not surprising to find that they are the most investigated for CH4-CO2 reforming. However, the main problem of Ni and Co catalysts in CH4-CO2 reforming is rapid deactivation as a result of coke deposition, sintering of metal particles, and/or metal oxidation. In particular, coke deposition becomes dominant at reduced temperatures. So far, a variety of Ni and Co catalysts were investigated for CH4-CO2 reforming [2,14], but only a small portion are for low-temperature CH4-CO2 reforming (i.e. below 873 K) [4–7,15–21]. It is noted that most of them were reported to be unstable at “low-temperature” conditions. It was demonstrated that hydrotalcite-like compounds (HTlcs) are effective precursors for the preparation of supported metal catalysts [22–29]. Also known as layered double hydroxides (LDHs), HTlcs are a class of two dimensional anionic clays that consist of positively charged brucite-like layers and exchangeable interlayer anions. They can be expressed as [M2+ 1- x M3+ x (OH)2] x +(An−) x /n·mH2O, where M2+ and M3+ represent divalent and trivalent metal ions within the brucite-like layers, and An- represents an interlayer anion. Ni-Mg-Al HTlcs have been widely used to prepare supported Ni catalysts. The catalysts show good activity and stability at high temperatures and appear to be one of the most effective catalysts for catalytic reforming of methane [30–33]. In comparison with the hydrotalcite-derived Ni catalysts, Co catalysts have received much less attention [34,35], especially so in low-temperature catalytic CH4-CO2 reforming. In this work, Mg(Al)O-supported Ni and Co catalysts prepared from Ni-Mg-Al HTlcs and Co-Mg-Al HTlcs, respectively, were tested for low-temperature CH4-CO2reforming under different reaction conditions. In previous studies [35,36], Ni and Co catalysts of different loadings prepared from HTlcs were characterized, and their catalytic performances for CH4-CO2 reforming were briefly compared without looking into the reason of performance discrepancy. In the present study, the performances of the Ni and Co catalysts were examined under a wide range of reaction conditions, i.e., T = 773–1023 K, CH4/CO2 = 1–2, WHSV = 60,000–120,000 mL h−1 g−1, and 25–200 h time-on-stream, with an aim to gain insights into the difference in catalytic behaviors. This is of practical importance considering that the reaction conditions can significantly affect catalyst stability as a result of coke deposition, metal sintering, and/or metal oxidation. Using techniques such as XRD, SEM, TEM, O2-TPO, kinetics measurement, CH4-TPSR, and direct CH4 decomposition test, we found that the Co catalyst is superior to the Ni catalyst in terms of catalytic stability and coke resistance at temperature as low as 773 K. The results highlight the potential use of the former for low-temperature CH4-CO2 reforming. To the best of our knowledge, the hydrotalcite-derived Co/Mg(Al)O is among the most effective non-precious metal catalysts reported so far for low-temperature CH4-CO2 reforming. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Mg(Al)O-supported Ni and Co catalysts were prepared by calcination and reduction of Ni-Mg-Al HTlcs and Co-Mg-Al HTlcs, respectively. Ni-Mg-Al HTlcs and Co-Mg-Al HTlcs were synthesized by co-precipitation method as previously reported [35,36]. In brief, an aqueous mixed solution of Mg(NO3)2∙6H2O, Al(NO3)3∙9H2O, and Ni(NO3)2∙6H2O or Co(NO3)2∙6H2O was slowly added into Na2CO3 aqueous solution under stirring at room temperature and pH = 10 ± 0.5. The resulting precipitate was filtered out, washed, and dried at 373 K for 12 h, followed by calcination in air at 1073 K for 5 h. The prepared catalysts are denoted herein as 12%Ni/Mg3Al and 12%Co/Mg3Al, where the metal weight percentage is 12% and the (Ni + Mg)/Al or (Co + Mg)/Al atomic ratio is 3. The metal contents were calculated according to the nominal compositions, which were confirmed by ICP analysis on the as-synthesized HTlcs precursors. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis was performed on OPTIMA 8000 with the as-synthesized precipitate dissolved in diluted nitric acid. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out on a PANalytical X’PertPro diffractometer using Co Kα radiation (λ = 0.1789 nm) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was conducted on a Hitachi-S4800 operated at 5.0 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed on a JEM-2100 (JEOL) microscope operated at 200 kV. Temperature-programmed oxidation (O2-TPO) and temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) of CH4 were performed on Micrometrics AutoChem 2920 connected to a mass spectrometer (Hiden Analytical HPR20). O2-TPO was applied to analyze coke deposition on the spent catalysts: 40 mg of spent catalyst was used and TPO was performed in 3%O2/Ar gas (flow rate = 30 mL min−1) from ambient temperature to 1273 K (heating rate = 10 K min−1). The m/e = 44 mass signal was used to monitor CO2 generation. For CH4-TPSR, 50 mg of catalyst was loaded and pre-reduced with H2 at 1073 K for 0.5 h. After the catalyst was cooled to ambient temperature in an Ar flow, a 10%CH4/Ar gas flow (30 mL min-1) was introduced into the reactor and then the temperature was raised to 1073 (10 K min−1). The consumption of CH4 and the formation of H2 were monitored by following the m/e = 16 and 2 mass signals, respectively. After CH4-TPSR, the catalyst was purged with N2 and cooled to ambient temperature, and then 3%O2/Ar was introduced into the reactor for O2-TPO measurement. 2.3 Catalytic reactions The catalytic reaction of CH4-CO2 reforming was performed in a fixed-bed quartz tube reactor (inner diameter 6 mm) at atmosphere pressure. Typically, 50 mg of catalyst was loaded and the catalyst was in situ reduced with H2 (30 mL min−1) at 1073 K for 0.5 h. After the catalyst was cooled down to the designated reaction temperature in N2 flow, the reactant gas was introduced into the reactor to start the reaction. The reactor effluent gas was analyzed by on-line TCD gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2014) using N2 as internal standard. For stability tests, the reaction was conducted at various conditions, i.e., T = 773–1023 K, CH4/CO2/N2 = 25/25/50–50/25/25, WHSV = 60,000–120,000 mL h−1g−1, and on-stream time of 25, 100, or 200 h. For kinetic measurements, the reaction was conducted at 773 K and WHSV = 120,000 mL h−1 g−1, and the reactant gas composition was varied from CH4/CO2/N2 = 20/25/55 to 30/25/45 and 25/20/55 to 25/30/45. For each test, the activity was evaluated for 15 min. Under the adopted conditions, CH4 conversion was below 15%. The catalytic reaction of direct CH4 decomposition was also performed on the same apparatus: 50 mg of catalyst was used and pre-reduced with H2 at 1073 K for 0.5 h. The reaction was conducted at 773 K and WHSV = 60,000 mL h−1 g−1 with 20%CH4/N2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance for CH4-CO2 reforming Fig. 1 shows the high-temperature catalytic performances over the 12%Ni/Mg3Al and 12%Co/Mg3Al catalysts. The reaction was conducted at 1023 K, CH4/CO2/N2 = 25/25/50, and WHSV = 60,000 mL h−1 g−1. Typically, the CO2 conversion was higher than the CH4 conversion and the ratio of H2/CO was below one because of the reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS). Both the Ni and Co catalysts showed relatively high activity at 1023 K. The conversions of CH4 and CO2 and the H2/CO ratio were about 88.0%, 93.6%, and 0.85 for the Ni catalyst, and 86.7%, 92.7%, and 0.85 for the Co catalyst, respectively. These values are close to those of thermodynamic equilibrium (87.0% CH4, 93.5% CO2, H2/CO = 0.94) calculated based on the CH4-CO2 reforming and reverse water-gas shift reactions. Moreover, both catalysts showed similar catalytic stability in 200 h. The good performance of the Ni and Co catalysts at 1023 K illustrates the effectiveness of using HTlcs for catalyst preparation. Fig. 2 shows the low-temperature catalytic performances obtained at 773 K over the 12%Ni/Mg3Al and 12%Co/Mg3Al catalysts. Unlike the reactions that were conducted at 1023 K, there is difference in catalytic performance between the two catalysts when the reaction temperature was 773 K. To study the influence of space velocity and CH4/CO2 ratio on the low-temperature catalytic performance, the reaction was performed under different conditions, i.e., (i) CH4/CO2/N2 = 25/25/50, WHSV = 60,000 mL h−1 g−1, (ii) CH4/CO2/N2 = 25/25/50, WHSV = 120,000 mL h−1 g−1, and (iii) CH4/CO2/N2 = 50/25/25, WHSV = 120,000 mL h−1 g−1. For the Ni catalyst, there was obvious change of CH4 and CO2 conversions and H2/CO ratio with on-stream time, where the values increased at the initial few hours and then decreased. According to calculations, the CH4 and CO2 conversions and H2/CO ratio at equilibrium under the conditions of 773 K and CH4/CO2 = 1 are 18.2%, 29.5% and 0.62, respectively. However, as shown in Fig. 2a, the maximum CH4 conversion and H2/CO ratio reached 21% and 0.77, which are higher than the equilibrium values. This phenomenon might be related to coke deposition as a result of direct CH4 decomposition (vide infra). Similar behavior was observed by Debek and co-workers [19 20] over hydrotalcite-derived Ni/Mg(Al)O catalysts and their Ce- and La-modified counterparts at 823 K, CH4/CO2/Ar = 10/10/80, and GHSV = 20,000 h−1. In comparison with the Ni catalyst, the Co catalyst exhibited much higher catalytic stability even at temperature as low as 773 K and at higher WHSV and CH4/CO2 ratio. Both CH4 and CO2 conversions remained stable in 25 h time-on-stream, evidencing catalytic stability superior to that of the Ni catalyst. It is noted that at 773 K and WHSV = 60,000 mL h−1 g−1, the conversions of CH4 and CO2 and H2/CO ratio on the Co catalyst are close to those of thermodynamic equilibrium, and are somewhat decreased at a WHSV as high as 120,000 mL h−1 g−1. To further verify the catalytic stability of the 12%Co/Mg3Al catalyst, a test of 100 h was carried out at 773 K, CH4/CO2/N2 = 25/25/50, and WHSV = 120,000 mL h−1 g−1. As shown in Fig. 3 , the Co catalyst displayed stable activity in the period of investigation. As far as we know, only a small number of Ni and Co catalysts were reported to show stable activity for CH4-CO2 reforming below 873 K (Supplementary materials, Table S1). For example, Sokolov et al. [7]. reported a mesoporous La2O3-ZrO2-supported Ni catalyst that showed stable activity under the conditions of 673 K, CH4/CO2/N2 = 10/10/80, and WHSV = 7200 mL h−1 g−1 in an on-stream time of 180 h. Also, El Hassan et al. [4]. observed stable activity in an on-stream time of 9 h over a Co catalyst that used mesoporous SiO2 (SBA-15) as support under the conditions of 823 K, CH4/CO2 = 50/50, and WHSV = 67,000 mL h−1 g−1. Despite a direct comparison is difficult due to difference in reaction conditions, it is reasonable to consider that the hydrotalcite-derived Co/Mg(Al)O catalyst is among the most effective non-precious metal catalysts reported so far for low-temperature CH4-CO2 reforming in terms of catalytic stability. 3.2 Characterization of spent catalysts To understand why the Co catalyst shows higher catalytic stability than the Ni catalyst in low-temperature CO2-CH4 reforming, the spent catalysts were characterized by XRD, SEM, TEM, and O2-TPO techniques. As an example, the results obtained on the spent catalysts after 25 h of reaction at 773 K, CH4/CO2/N2 = 25/25/50, and WHSV = 120,000 mL h−1 g−1 (Fig. 2c–d) are presented in Figs. 4–6 , and those of the other cases are given in Figs. S1–S3 (Supplementary materials). Fig. 4 shows the XRD patterns of the spent catalysts as well as those of the freshly reduced ones for reference. For the reduced Ni and Co catalysts, the XRD patterns could be related to Ni metal and Mg(Ni, Al)O mixed oxide of 12%Ni/Mg3Al [36], and Co metal and Mg(Co, Al)O mixed oxide of 12%Co/Mg3Al [35]. As reported [22,35,36], calcination of Ni-Mg-Al HTlcs (or Co-Mg-Al HTlcs) gave rise to a MgO-like rock-salt-type mixed oxide, in which Al3+ and Ni2+ (or Co2+) ions were incorporated into the MgO framework to form a solid solution. Upon reduction at 1073 K, a part of Ni2+ (or Co2+) ions were reduced and migrated out of the solid solution to yield small metal particles on the surface. It should be noted that the complete reduction of Ni2+ (or Co2+) species requires high temperature (>1223 K) because of their strong interaction with MgO. According to TEM measurement, the sizes of the resulting Ni° and Co° particles were ∼10.8 and 10.1 nm, respectively [22 35]. Compared with the XRD pattern of the reduced Ni catalyst, that of the spent Ni catalyst showed a strong peak at 2θ = 30.3° attributable to graphite, whereas such a signal was not observed on the spent Co catalyst. The XRD results give clear evidence that coking is severe on the Ni catalyst and it is not so in the case of Co catalyst. Displayed in Fig. 5 are the SEM and TEM images of the spent catalysts. In the case of Ni catalyst, the HRTEM image shows clear presence of a large amount of carbon filaments, and on the top of each is decorated with a pear-shape particle (Fig. 5b, inset). According to ∑nidi 3/∑nidi 2, the average size of the Ni metal particles was estimated to be ∼12.0 nm, slightly larger than the reduced catalyst. For the spent Co catalyst, carbon filaments were only found occasionally on the surface and their length was much shorter as compared to those of the spent Ni catalyst. From the TEM image, the average size of the Co metal particles was estimated to be ∼9.2 nm, slightly smaller than those of the reduced catalyst. It seems that sintering of metal particles was not severe on these two catalysts under the low-temperature conditions. Fig. 6 shows the O2-TPO profiles of surface coke on the spent catalysts. To see the change of coke deposition with time on stream, the catalyst was sampled at different time intervals when subjected to O2-TPO measurement. For the 12%Ni/Mg3Al catalyst, the CO2 peak was observed at >820 K, which became stronger and shifted toward higher temperatures with time. This CO2 peak could be attributed to the oxidation of well-crystalline graphite, such as the filamentous carbon detected in XRD, SEM, and TEM investigations. For the 12%Co/Mg3Al catalyst, there were three small CO2 peaks ascribable to three types of carbon. The CO2 peak at ∼573 K could be assigned to monoatomic carbon intermediate (CH x ) arising from the dissociation of CH4, and the peak at ∼733 K to encapsulating carbon, while the peak at >820 K to filamentous carbon. It can be seen that the monoatomic carbon was dominant within the initial 2.5 h and increased only slightly with time, whereas those encapsulating and filamentous carbons gradually increased and became significant in the 10 h of reaction. The amount of coke deposition was calculated by integrating the CO2 peaks and plotted against time (Fig. 6c). Obviously, the amount of coke and the rate of coke deposition over 12%Co/Mg3Al were much lower than those over 12%Ni/Mg3Al. Particularly, at the beginning of the reaction, the rate of coke deposition on 12%Ni/Mg3Al (93.6 mg-C h−1 gcat −1) was about 20 times that on 12%Co/Mg3Al (4.3 mg-C h−1 gcat −1). The difference would become more significant if only the encapsulating and filamentous carbons on the 12%Co/Mg3Al catalyst were considered. This result combined with those of XRD, SEM, and TEM analyses clearly demonstrates the superior coke-resistance ability of 12%Co/Mg3Al in comparison to that of 12%Ni/Mg3Al in low-temperature CH4-CO2 reforming. Table 1 summarizes the nature of coke deposition over the 12%Ni/Mg3Al and 12%Co/Mg3Al catalysts under different reaction conditions. At reaction temperature of 1023 K, the coke deposition and coking rate on both catalysts were low and similar to each other, suggesting that both catalysts were similarly effective in suppressing coke deposition at high temperature. However, when the reaction temperature decreased from 1023 K to 773 K, the coking rate on the Ni catalyst increased remarkably (∼340 times). In comparison, the coking rate on the Co catalyst increased in a lesser extent (∼30 times). Generally, after reaction at 773 K for 25 h, the coke deposition on the Co catalyst was about one-ninth that of the Ni catalyst. At higher CH4/CO2 ratio, the Co catalyst also showed lower coke deposition (∼one-third), although the coke deposition increased to some extent as compared to that under stoichiometry of CH4/CO2 = 1. It should be noted that when the time on stream was prolonged from 25 h to 100 h, coke deposition on the Co catalyst only increased slightly. Despite a test of longer time would be more confirmative, it is reasonable to conclude that the Co catalyst is coke resistant for low-temperature CH4-CO2 reforming. Listed in Table S1 are the coking rates recorded over reported catalysts. Despite deviation in reaction temperature, reactant gas composition, space velocity, and on-stream time as well as measurement method, it can be sure that the Co catalyst is among the few that show both stable activity and good coke resistance. Especially, it is noted that the coking rate on the Co catalyst was 1–2 orders of magnitude lower than those of hydrotalcite-derived Ni catalysts and their Ce-, Zr-, La-modified counterparts, even though the reaction conditions in the Co case were more severe. According to suggested mechanism [37–39], CH4 dissociates on metal surfaces to form CH x (x = 0–3) species, and the carbon species are gasified by the oxygen derived from CO2 to yield CO and H2. Alternatively, the carbon species may dissolve into the metal crystallite and subsequently diffuse through the particle to precipitate at the rear, leading to the formation of filamentous carbon, or accumulate on the metal surface to form encapsulating carbon. Hence a balance of CH4 dissociation rate, carbon gasification rate, and carbon precipitation rate is important to control coke deposition. 3.3 Kinetics study for low-temperature CH4-CO2 reforming To understand the coke-deposition behaviors of the 12%Ni/Mg3Al and 12%Co/Mg3Al catalysts in low-temperature CH4-CO2 reforming, the related kinetics and catalytic behavior for direct CH4 decomposition were investigated. The effect of CH4 and CO2 partial pressures on the catalyst activity was investigated by varying the reactant gas composition from CH4/CO2/N2 = 20/25/55 to 30/25/45 and 25/20/55 to 25/30/45. At 773 K and WHSV = 120,000 mL h−1 g−1, CH4 and CO2 conversions (<15% and <20%, respectively) are below the thermodynamic equilibrium values (18.2% and 29.5%, respectively) (Fig. 2d). For kinetic measurements, experiments were performed under the same conditions at a reactant gas composition of CH4/CO2/N2 = 25/25/50. The obtained results are presented in Fig. 7 and Table S2 (Supplementary materials). When the partial pressure of CH4 was raised from 20% to 30% (Fig. 7a), there was increase of CH4 conversion rate. The reaction orders of CH4 were determined to be ∼0.34 and 0.44 for the Ni and Co catalysts, respectively. The lower reaction order of CH4 implies that CH4 was more strongly adsorbed on Ni than on Co. This is in part supported by the result of CH4-TPSR that Ni metal was more active for CH4 dissociation than Co metal (vide infra). It is widely accepted that CH4 dissociation is the rate-determining step for CH4 reforming reactions. The activation energy for the activation of the first CH bond of CH4 was estimated by density-functional theory to be 1.02–1.23 eV on Co(111) surfaces [40–42], which are higher than the values of 0.85∼0.91 eV on Ni(111) surfaces [39,43,44]. This may partially explain why the activity of Co/Mg(Al)O was lower than that of Ni/Mg(Al)O for CH4 dissociation, although it must be emphasized that the activation energy may vary with the use of support materials [42]. Because the activity for CH4 dissociation is lower in the case of Co/Mg(Al)O, there is reduction of carbon formation rate and suppression of carbon accumulation. With the rise of CO2 partial pressure from 20% to 30% (Fig. 7b), the CH4 reaction rate on the Ni catalyst increased while that on the Co catalyst decreased. The reaction order of CH4 was calculated to be ∼0.20 for the Ni catalyst and −0.57 for the Co catalyst. The results suggest that CO2 was more strongly adsorbed on the Co catalyst than on the Ni catalyst, and the former has higher affinity for CO2 adsorption than the latter. According to Budiman et al. [14]. over metal catalysts with supports of acidic nature, dissociative adsorption of CO2 proceeds on the metal to yield surface CO* and O*, whereas in the cases of basic supports, CO2 is activated on the support in the vicinity of the metal particles to form carbonate species. In the present study, with basic Mg(Al)O as support, CO2 activation is likely to proceed at the metal-support interfaces. Since Co metal is more oxophilic than Ni metal [45], the formation of carbonate on Co-Mg(Al)O would be heavier than that on Ni-Mg(Al)O. On the other hand, although the CO2 activation on the metal surface may be limited as compared to that at the metal-support interface, the dissociative adsorption of CO2 is expected to occur more easily on the Co metal surface than on the Ni metal surface because the former is of higher oxophilicity and displays stronger binding to oxygen as stated by Tu et al. [45]. Conclusively, the oxophilic property of Co promotes CO2 activation at the Co-Mg(Al)O interface as well as on the Co metal surface. This conception is in part supported by the negative reaction order of CH4, which may be interpreted as due to the oxidation of Co metal by CO2 as observed on Co/Al2O3, Co/MgO, and Co/TiO2 catalysts in CH4-CO2 reforming [46–52]. Based on the CH4 conversion at 773 K and the number of surface metal atoms (70.2 μmol-Ni gcat −1 [36] and 56.3 μmol-Co gcat −1 [35]), the TOF of CH4 was calculated to be 0.81 s−1 for 12%Co/Mg3Al, slightly higher than that (0.72 s−1) for 12%Ni/Mg3Al. This might be attributed to the enhanced activation of CO2 on the Co catalyst that promoted carbon gasification. The activation of CO2 is an important step in CH4-CO2 reforming [38 39], where CO2 yields reactive oxygen species that oxidize CH x species to produce CO and H2. The enhanced activation of CO2 at the Co-Mg(Al)O interface and on the Co metal surface results in higher quantity of reactive oxygen species, thus promoting the gasification of carbonous species. Just recently, Tu et al. [45]. claimed that an adsorbed oxygen atom and a vicinal Co atom may interact to form a metal-oxygen site pair for the activation of CH bond following a σ bond metathesis route through a four-center (H3C*HO*) transition state. The direct involvement of reactive oxygen in the CH activation step would lead to high CH4 turnover and effective suppression of coke deposition. 3.4 Catalytic behavior of direct CH4 decomposition The behaviors of direct CH4 decomposition on the 12%Ni/Mg3Al and 12%Co/Mg3Al catalysts were investigated by CH4-TPSR (Fig. 8 (a)). For the Ni catalyst, CH4 decomposition started at ∼623 K showing a sharp peak at 807 K with a small shoulder peak at 634 K. As for the Co catalyst, CH4 decomposition started at ∼673 K, showing a strong and broad peak at 845 K and a small shoulder peak at 700 K. In comparison with the Ni catalyst, the Co catalyst displayed CH4-TPSR profile that was higher in temperature and broader in the main peak. This suggests that the Co catalyst was less active for CH4 dissociation than the Ni catalyst, in agreement with the kinetic data. The nature and reactivity of the carbon originated from CH4 decomposition were further investigated by O2-TPO measurement. As shown in Fig. 8(b), CO2 peaks located at 723 K and 923 K for the Ni catalyst, and at 695 K and 880 K for the Co catalyst attributable to encapsulating carbon and filamentous carbon, respectively, were observed. Obviously, the temperature for carbon oxidation was lower in the case of Co catalyst, meaning that the deposited carbon on Co metal could be more easily removed by oxygen in comparison with that on Ni metal. It is envisioned that in low-temperature CH4-CO2 reforming, the carbon species on the Co catalyst can be gasified more readily by the oxygen atoms derived from CO2 dissociation, resulting in promoted carbon gasification and inhibition of carbon deposition. The steady-state activity of direct CH4 decomposition was also tested over the 12%Ni/Mg3Al and 12%Co/Mg3Al catalysts. Fig. 9 shows the change of CH4 conversion at 773 K with time on stream. For the Ni catalyst, the CH4 conversion decreased slightly within the initial 30 min and then gradually increased to a maximum at 100 min. What followed was the decline of CH4 conversion to near zero at 270 min. Such a trend was similar to those of CH4 conversion in CH4-CO2 reforming (Fig. 2a, c & e). It is thus deduced that the large coke deposition on the Ni catalyst in low-temperature CH4-CO2 reforming is mainly a result of CH4 decomposition. Compared with the Ni catalyst, the Co catalyst showed much lower activity for CH4 decomposition; the initial CH4 conversion on the Co catalyst (4.2%) was roughly one-third that on the Ni catalyst (15.2%). This is in agreement with the results of CH4-TPSR investigation, indicating that Co metal was less active for CH4 dissociation than Ni metal under the adopted conditions (773 K). Another important point is that the Co catalyst showed much lower stability for CH4 decomposition, where CH4 conversion decreased quickly and reached zero within 60 min. The O2-TPO results of spent catalysts (Supplementary materials, Fig. S4) showed that coke deposition on the Co catalyst (8.4 wt%) was about one-fifth that on the Ni catalyst (40.2 wt%). That the activity for CH4 decomposition at temperatures below 873 K was lower on Co than that on Ni was also observed over the SiO2-, Al2O3-, and CeO2/MgO/Al2O3-supported catalysts [53–56]. It is well known that the catalytic activity and stability of metal catalysts for CH4 decomposition is under the influence of reaction temperature [54]. To discard the effect of reaction temperature in the investigation, CH4 decomposition was performed at the temperature equal to that adopted for CH4-CO2 reforming. According to the well-known deposition-diffusion-precipitation mechanism widely used to explain the growth of carbon filaments in hydrocarbon decomposition [57–59], the carbon atoms generated from the dissociation of hydrocarbon molecules on a metal surface diffuse to the other side of the metal particles to form carbon filaments. At the steady state, carbon generation, diffusion, and precipitation are similar in rate. However, when the rate of carbon generation is higher than those of diffusion and precipitation, there is carbon accumulation and formation of encapsulating carbon layer, resulting in catalyst deactivation and cease of carbon filament growth. According to the results of CH4-TPSR and CH4 decomposition experiments, the Co catalyst was less effective for the formation of filamentous carbon in CH4 decomposition than the Ni catalyst. On this basis, it is deduced that on the Ni catalyst the rates of carbon generation, diffusion, and precipitation were comparable, thus yielding a large amount of carbon filaments. In the case of Co catalyst, the rates of carbon diffusion and precipitation were much lower than that of carbon generation, leading to rapid decline of CH4 decomposition activity. In H2-TPR studies, the reduction peak of Mg(Co, Al)O was located at temperature higher than that of Mg(Ni, Al)O (Supplementary materials, Fig. S5). Between the Ni catalyst and Co catalyst, carbon diffusion and precipitation on the Co catalyst were less effective, plausibly due to stronger metal-support interaction of the latter as inferred by the results of H2-TPR investigation [35,36]. A strong metal-support interaction would result in lowering of carbon precipitation at the metal-support interface, thus inhibits the growth of filamentous carbon and induces rapid accumulation of carbon on the metal surface, causing rapid deactivation of catalyst as a result. Based on the above results, the difference in catalytic stability and coke resistance between the Ni/Mg(Al)O and Co/Mg(Al)O catalysts can be ascribed to factors such as activity of CH4 and CO2 activation and metal-support interaction. The higher stability and coke resistance of the Co catalyst can be attributed to its lower activity for CH4 dissociation/decomposition and higher affinity for CO2 adsorption as well as its stronger metal-support interaction. With lower activity for CH dissociation, the rate of carbon formation is reduced, and with higher affinity for CO2 adsorption, the activation of CO bonds to yield reactive oxygen species is promoted, collectively enhancing the gasification of carbonous species and inhibiting coke deposition. Here it should be mentioned that a balance of carbon and oxygen species on the metal surface is important for catalytic stability. When there is dominance of carbon species, deactivation due to coke deposition would occur; on the other hand, when the surface is predominant with active oxygen species, catalyst deactivation as a result of metal oxidation would happen. Since Co metal is highly oxophilic, the presence of carbon species has to be sufficient to prevent surface metallic Co from being oxidized by oxygen species. In this respect, the effect of strong metal-support interaction between Co and Mg(Al)O becomes important. It is because with the retardation of carbon deposition at the metal-support interface, more active carbon species are available on the surfaces of metallic Co. It is apparent that a good balance between CH4 and CO2 activation as well as a suitable level of metal-support interaction on the Co/Mg(Al)O catalyst is required for satisfactory performance. On the contrary, in the case of Ni/Mg(Al)O, the catalyst has higher activity for CH4 dissociation/decomposition and lower affinity for CO2 adsorption as well as weaker metal-support interaction. Particularly, the high activity for CH4 decomposition is considered to be the main reason for large coke deposition. 4 Conclusions The catalytic performances of hydrotalcite-derived Mg(Al)O-supported Ni and Co catalysts for CH4-CO2 reforming were compared and it was found that the Co catalyst exhibited low-temperature catalytic performance superior to that of the Ni catalyst in terms of catalytic stability and coke resistance. Under the reaction conditions of T = 773–1023 K, CH4/CO2/N2 = 25/25/50–50/25/25, and WHSV = 60,000–120,000 mL h−1 g−1, the Co catalyst showed stable activity and high coke resistance not only at 1023 K but also at temperature as low as 773 K. In contrast, although the Ni catalyst showed good stability at 1023 K, it readily deactivated at 773 K due to severe coking. At 773 K, the initial coking rate on the Co catalyst was estimated to be ∼1/20 that on the Ni catalyst. These results illustrate that the hydrotalcite-derived Co/Mg(Al)O is a potential catalyst for low-temperature CH4-CO2 reforming. The results of kinetic measurement suggest that the dissociative adsorption of CH4 is less favored on the Co catalyst, and the Co catalyst has higher affinity for CO2 adsorption. Furthermore, CH4-TPSR and CH4 decomposition activity tests revealed that the Co catalyst was much less active for carbon formation in CH4 decomposition than the Ni catalyst. The high activity of Ni for CH4 decomposition is the main cause of heavy coking. It is considered that the high coke-resistance ability of the Co catalyst is a combined result of low activity for CH4 dissociation/decomposition, high affinity for CO2 adsorption, and strong metal-support interaction. coredata.dc:description: The Co catalyst using hydrotalcite-derived Mg(Al)O as support shows promising catalytic activity for low-temperature CH4-CO2 reforming. Under a wide range of reaction conditions, that is T = 773–1023 K, CH4/CO2/N2 = 25/25/50–50/25/25, WHSV = 60,000–120,000 mL h−1 g−1, and TOS = 25–200 h, the Co catalyst exhibits stable activity and high coke resistance. The performance is superior to the Ni counterpart which readily deactivates at 773 K due to severe coke deposition. The initial coking rate on the Co catalyst was estimated to be about 1/20 times that on the Ni catalyst. The kinetic study suggests that the dissociative adsorption of CH4 is favored on the Ni catalyst, whereas the Co catalyst has high affinity for CO2 adsorption. The results of CH4-TPSR and direct CH4 decomposition experiments further reveal that the Co catalyst is much less active for carbon formation through CH4 decomposition. It is deduced that a combination of lower activity for CH4 dissociation/decomposition and higher affinity for CO2 adsorption as well as a stronger metal-support interaction is responsible for the higher coke resistance of the Co catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrotalcite-derived Co/Mg(Al)O as a stable and coke-resistant catalyst for low-temperature carbon dioxide reforming of methane
